utter_en:
The Oberrein refers to the section of the Rhine from Basel to Bingen. It is 360 km long. Along the Oberrein, there are floodplain areas that can be flooded at times. These are also called Auen. The Auen provide habitat for many animal and plant species. Many bird species also winter here.
Only about 10% of the Oberrein's original Auen have remained. What is the reason for this? There are several causes for the significant decline in Auen. One reason is the straightening of the Rhine by Johann Gottfried Tulla in the 19th century. Other reasons include the earlier construction of the high water dam and the further development of the Oberrein with its reservoirs.
Here's an interesting fact: The Oberrein is one of the largest groundwater reservoirs in Europe!

River landscapes belong to the most endangered natural habitats. They are also threatened along the Upper Rhine.
Human beings strongly intervene in nature. As a result, river landscapes are disappearing more and more. The main cause of the disappearance of river landscapes is the straightening of rivers. For this, banks are reinforced, dams are built, and reservoirs and weirs are constructed.
As a result, more and more floodplains, also called Auen, are disappearing. The river loses its natural dynamics. However, this natural dynamics is important for the formation of typical Auen habitats.

The change from high and low water determines the living conditions along the Rhine River. The river has shaped the floodplain here. In the Rhine valley, you will find softwood and hardwood floodplain forests, still and flowing waters, marshes, and meadows.
